story:
Not much time left if you want to fund this project. Please press the pink box if you think Naploo deserves a chance. Even $1 can make a difference!
*****
What is Naploo?

It is an interactive online diary that you can share, and even co-author with your friends

How is Naploo different from a blog?

- It is interactive: your friends can edit your posts, if you allow them

- It has a user-friendly interface and a tool set that makes writing your diary a fun experience

- The advanced search function helps you find posts about specific friends, places, activities, etc.

How is Naploo different from Facebook?

While you may use it to keep in touch with your friends, its main purpose is to help you preserve your greatest memories in a fun way

Why will people love Naploo?

- You think you do not need Naploo? Think again! Has it ever happened to you that you wanted to remember an old friend, a holiday abroad, or just a feeling, but you were unable to? We slowly lose our past as our memories fade away – but it should not be like that!

Thanks to its advanced search function, Naploo lets you relive the whole story of a friendship or a love affair (how it all began, the things you did together, the occasional conflicts), or how your kids grew up, with just a few clicks.

You can share your posts with your friends, so that they also remember the fun you had together. If you let them, they can also comment on what you wrote, and even edit it, adding details or pictures.

It is as if you made a photo album for your thoughts and experiences. You put them in an imaginary chest, where, as time passes, they turn into a treasure.

- The popularity of Facebook, Twitter and similar platforms is based in great part on the fact that people like to show the world who they are and what they are up to. They may have never thought about writing a diary, but they certainly like to write about themselves.

- It is easy and fun to use Naploo – you do not need to write a novel every time.

Where is the money?

- There may be advertisements on Naploo

- You may have to pay for some services, like additional skin options or special fonts

Example 1:

“Friday, May 19, 2017: We went to the zoo with Andy, Bart and Cindy. I haven’t seen Cindy for a long time, and it was great to catch up with her. We saw a cute baby elephant, and the polar bear was cool, too, like a giant teddy bear. After the zoo, we had an ice cream.”

You share your Naploo post with Andy, Bart and Cindy. You allow them to edit and comment on what you wrote. (Of course, you can change your mind and delete their contribution any time.)

Bart changes the post as follows:

“Friday, May 19, 2017: We went to the zoo with Andy, Bart and Cindy. I haven’t seen Cindy for a long time, and it was great to catch up with her. We saw a cute baby elephant, [picture] and the polar bear [picture] was cool, too, like a giant teddy bear. The zebra was breastfeeding its foal [picture]. After the zoo, we had an ice cream.”

Cindy does not edit the post, but she comments on it, either below the text, or in a thought bubble, which she can “stick” to whichever part of the post she chooses. (You can later move it.)

Cindy’s comment: “Going to the zoo was a great idea, and so was the ice cream. It was nice to see you!”

An important part of Naploo is that it makes it easy for you to find and group your posts. There are three ways of tagging parts of the text (underlined, bolded and italicized in the above example).

- Underlined: tagged automatically by Naploo, e.g. dates. You can check any time what you did on May 19, 2017.

- Bolded: suggested by Naploo to be tagged, e.g. names. You can accept or reject the suggestion. In this way, it will be easy to find all the things that you did with Andy since you met him.

- Italicized: tagged by you without input from Naploo. You can later check when you last went to a zoo, how many times you have been there in the past ten years, etc.

When you hover over the [picture] icons added to your post by Bart, the picture of the baby elephant/polar bear/zebra foal appears. You can link whole albums to a post (yours or someone else’s).

Example 2:

“Tuesday, January 5, 2016: Little Katie made her first steps today! I couldn’t believe my eyes; she’s not even one year old! I’m so proud of her.”

You share this post with all your friends on Naploo, so that they can see its title/fist line/etc. on their message board. This time, no one is allowed to edit the text, but comments are welcome.

You can attach pictures and videos to the post.

Later, you can easily find Katie’s adventures and funny quotes from her childhood. In time, you will treasure these special moments, and so will Katie, and eventually her children. Without Naploo, how many of these moments would you remember?

You want to compile a book on Katie’s first couple of years (e.g. for her grandparents)? It is easy to do with Naploo’s advanced search function, and the possibility to export texts.

Other features of Naploo:

- You can link your posts to those of your friends, if they allow it. You can even import whole posts from a friend.

- You can chat with friends on Naploo (and there are other features that make it a fun experience, even when you do not write your diary)

- Naploo can help you organize meetings with your friends, or find people for an activity you want to do, like hiking or going to the cinema

- Customizable appearance (skins, fonts, etc.)

- Predefined categories to further help you group and find your posts (New Year’s Commitments, thoughts of the day, all the good things that happened today/this week, memorable dreams, love/family, holidays, books/movies/sports events, etc.)

Naploo has the potential to become an integral, and very precious, part of your life, even if you have never thought about writing a diary before.

The money raised here will be used to hire programmers, who will create an MVP (minimum viable product), that may in turn attract investors.

Please share – some of your friends may be interested in supporting Naploo!

Not much time left if you want to fund this project. Please press the pink box if you think Naploo deserves a chance. Even $1 can make a difference!*****What is Naploo?
It is an interactive online
diary that you can share, and even co-author with your friends
How is Naploo different from a blog?
- It is interactive: your
friends can edit your posts, if you allow them
- It has a user-friendly interface
and a tool set that makes writing your diary a fun experience
- The advanced search
function helps you find posts about specific friends, places, activities, etc.
How is Naploo different from Facebook?
While you may use it to
keep in touch with your friends, its main purpose is to help you preserve your
greatest memories in a fun way
Why will people love Naploo?
- You think you do not need
Naploo? Think again! Has it ever happened to you that you wanted to remember an
old friend, a holiday abroad, or just a feeling, but you were unable to? We
slowly lose our past as our memories fade away – but it should not be like
that!
Thanks to its advanced
search function, Naploo lets you relive the whole story of a friendship or a
love affair (how it all began, the things you did together, the occasional
conflicts), or how your kids grew up, with just a few clicks.
You can share your posts
with your friends, so that they also remember the fun you had together. If you
let them, they can also comment on what you wrote, and even edit it, adding
details or pictures.
It is as if you made a
photo album for your thoughts and experiences. You put them in an imaginary
chest, where, as time passes, they turn into a treasure.
- The popularity of
Facebook, Twitter and similar platforms is based in great part on the fact that
people like to show the world who they are and what they are up to. They may
have never thought about writing a diary, but they certainly like to write
about themselves.
- It is easy and fun to use
Naploo – you do not need to write a novel every time.
Where is the money?
- There may be
advertisements on Naploo
- You may have to pay for
some services, like additional skin options or special fonts
Example 1:
“Friday, May 19, 2017:
We went to the zoo with Andy, Bart and Cindy. I
haven’t seen Cindy for a long time,
and it was great to catch up with her. We saw a cute baby elephant, and the
polar bear was cool, too, like a giant teddy bear. After the zoo, we had an ice
cream.”
You share your Naploo post
with Andy, Bart and Cindy. You allow them to edit and comment on what you wrote.
(Of course, you can change your mind and delete their contribution any time.)
Bart changes the post as
follows:
“Friday, May 19, 2017:
We went to the zoo with Andy, Bart and Cindy. I
haven’t seen Cindy for a long time,
and it was great to catch up with her. We saw a cute baby elephant, [picture] and the polar bear [picture] was cool, too, like a giant teddy bear. The
zebra was breastfeeding its foal [picture]. After
the zoo, we had an ice cream.”
Cindy does not edit the
post, but she comments on it, either below the text, or in a thought bubble,
which she can “stick” to whichever part of the post she chooses. (You can later
move it.)
Cindy’s comment: “Going to
the zoo was a great idea, and so was the ice cream. It was nice to see you!”
An important part of Naploo
is that it makes it easy for you to find and group your posts. There are three
ways of tagging parts of the text (underlined, bolded and italicized in
the above example).
- Underlined: tagged
automatically by Naploo, e.g. dates. You can check any time what you did on May
19, 2017.
- Bolded: suggested by Naploo to be tagged, e.g. names. You can
accept or reject the suggestion. In this way, it will be easy to find all the
things that you did with Andy since you met him.
- Italicized: tagged by you without input from Naploo. You can later
check when you last went to a zoo, how many times you have been there in the
past ten years, etc.
When you hover over the [picture] icons added to your post by Bart, the picture
of the baby elephant/polar bear/zebra foal appears. You can link whole albums
to a post (yours or someone else’s).
Example 2:
“Tuesday, January 5,
2016: Little Katie made her
first steps today! I couldn’t believe my eyes; she’s not even one year old! I’m
so proud of her.”
You share this post with
all your friends on Naploo, so that they can see its title/fist line/etc. on
their message board. This time, no one is allowed to edit the text, but
comments are welcome.
You can attach pictures and
videos to the post.
Later, you can easily find
Katie’s adventures and funny quotes from her childhood. In time, you will
treasure these special moments, and so will Katie, and eventually her children.
Without Naploo, how many of these moments would you remember?
You want to compile a book
on Katie’s first couple of years (e.g. for her grandparents)? It is easy to do
with Naploo’s advanced search function, and the possibility to export texts.
Other features of Naploo:
- You can link your posts to
those of your friends, if they allow it. You can even import whole posts from a
friend.
- You can chat with friends
on Naploo (and there are other features that make it a fun experience, even
when you do not write your diary)
- Naploo can help you
organize meetings with your friends, or find people for an activity you want to
do, like hiking or going to the cinema
- Customizable appearance
(skins, fonts, etc.)
- Predefined categories to
further help you group and find your posts (New Year’s Commitments, thoughts of
the day, all the good things that happened today/this week, memorable dreams,
love/family, holidays, books/movies/sports events, etc.)
Naploo has the potential to
become an integral, and very precious, part of your life, even if you have
never thought about writing a diary before.
The money raised here will
be used to hire programmers, who will create an MVP (minimum viable product),
that may in turn attract investors.
Please share – some of your friends may
be interested in supporting Naploo!

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Bienvenidos a mi campaña

Mi nombre es Valentina M, tengo 14 años y practico remo desde los 10 años.
Durante estos años, me he esforzado por tener una buena técnica, una buena disciplina y control en todos los aspectos de mi vida.  
En la fecha tengo propuestas para poder entrenarme con miras a  las próximas Olimpiadas, dado el buen rendimiento que he tenido, pero para lograr mis objetivos, tengo que participar en varias regatas nacionales, e internacionales, para que me puedan evaluar, y con suerte y dedicación poder ser parte del equipo Olímpico de Remo.  
Quisiera poder participar de las regatas que se realizaran en el mes de octubre en Perú, competencias que serán fundamentales para poder medir mi progreso en busca de la consecución de mis objetivos.
Se que lograr estas metas, no solo es importante para mi, sino también para mi equipo, mis entrenadores y mi familia que siempre me han alentado, y gracias a Dios siempre les he podido responder bien a las expectativas que han puesto en mi.
Espero también poder cumplir con las expectativas que usted como colaborador de mi campaña tenga, y poder llegar a clasificar al Equipo Olímpico con su ayuda.
Si estas listo para colaborar te diré que el dinero recaudado es para costear el viaje desde Buenos Aires a Perú, junto con un acompañante, ya que soy menor de edad y no puedo viajar sola, mas los gastos de alojamiento y comida, transportes en Perú, por espacio de 6 días, dos ciudades, dos regatas.
Si no lograra mis objetivos, el dinero recaudado no lo podría devolver, pues de todas formas se habrá de gastar para poder participar en las regatas.  Yo realmente confió en que puedo realizar un buen papel en las competencias, pero no podría garantizar el triunfo porque seria deshonesto de mi parte prometer algo que aunque tenga toda la gana, el deseo y la capacidad necesaria, solo el día de la competencia sabre si he logrado el triunfo.
Me gustaría contar con tu apoyo, y si Dios quiere cuando logre una medalla Olímpica, sientas el placer de decir yo colabore para que ese sueño se hiciera realidad.
Mi carrera en el Remo comenzo a los 10 años, y mi profesor, viendo las buenas condiciones que tenia, me sugirió un club de Remo donde pudieran explotar todo el potencial que desde un principio tenia.
Para mi primera competencia el profesor nos preparo psicologicamente para que no nos afectara la derrota, lo que no sabia nuestro profesor es que ese mismo día nos colgamos tres medallas.
Así he participado ya en muchas regatas. durante el ultimo año he participado en 8 regatas, de las cuales he ganado 7 medallas de Oro y una de plata.
No es un trabajo fácil, yo voy a la escuela,(donde me va muy bien),me levanto todos los días a las 5:30 a.m. hasta las 4:30 p.m. y llego a casa a las 6:00 p.m pues tengo mas de una hora de recorrido en tren.  Voy a entrenamiento los martes y jueves,  de 6:00 p.m.  a  8:00 p.m y sábados y domingos  voy de 9:00 a 11:00 a.m. y hago un doble turno de 2:00 a 4:00 p.m.  En lo posible no falto a ninguno de ellos, pues me he comprometido conmigo misma a hacer de este deporte algo importante en mi vida y lo estoy logrando, 
Se que aveces aunque uno quiera no puede colaborar, o no de la forma que uno quisiera, asi que te pido que si no puedes colaborar economicamente con esta campaña. no te desanimes y  te pido que compartas y difundas esta campaña con todos tus amigos y conocidos, puedes usar las herramientas de Indiegogo para difundirla.
Gracias por su apoyo
Valentina





        Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

        Algunas personas no pueden colaborar, pero eso no significa que no puedan ayudar:

        • pídele a la gente que difunda tu campaña y que genere eco.
        • Recuérdale que use las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.

        Y eso es todo.

story:
My church and i go to Haiti for missions trips multiple times throughout the year. coming up in January.

we are apart of an orphanage there. Destiny Village is a Christian orphanage in Pierre Payen, Haiti. basically the money I'm asking for is an idea to love beyond the boarders into this poverty stricken country.

but yet it thrives with wonderful smiles and people who are beautiful inside and out.

$1500.00  will cover my ticket to haiti $950.00 and

the rest will go toward blessing the kids in haiti.

1) shoes

2) rice and beans

3) towards education

4) and then blessing orphanages that thrive through

destiny village.

more future ideas is blessing the homeless here in my hometown. just showing Gods love for them in the city of tampa.

i will provide video of where the money went and how it was used to help the people in haiti and here at home.

simple acts of love through simply loving Jesus.

(all funding completely will go towards the things stated above)

mathew 22.39 " ‘Love your neighbor as yourself."

this is a video of us going to haiti in 2012

http://youtu.be/owsIgC-De8k

my name is meshack tapales

email is shackmt@gmail.com if you have any questions

story:
CHI SONO, LA MIA IDEA: 

Sono Adriana Redaelli, la  maggiore dei dodici figli di Riccardo e Rosa, nipote di Alfredo Redaelli e Maria Sala. Sono nata e cresciuta a Brogno e sono tornata ad abitarvi pochi anni fa.

Da un po’ di tempo ero alla ricerca di un’idea per celebrare la memoria dei nostri genitori. Infatti quest'anno  2014  ricorre il 100° anniversario della nascita di mia madre e il 110° di quella di mio padre.

Così è nato il progetto di questo libro che riporta alla luce la storia secolare della casa in cui siamo nati e cresciuti e quella della nostra famiglia.

Mia figlia Caterina ne è stata la coraggiosa ed entusiasta sostenitrice, ma contributi preziosi sono venuti da familiari, amici e conoscenti

Man mano che il lavoro procedeva persone, luoghi e vicende emergevano  dall’oscurità  e dal mistero e riprendevano vita.

Adesso il libro è pronto per la  stampa e siamo contenti.  Vi piacerà, vedrete.

LA STORIA

Nel contesto di una città  alcuni luoghi costituiscono veri e propri punti focali. Brogno, amena e silenziosa frazione di Rancio di Lecco ai piedi del monte S. Martino, è uno di questi luoghi.

Domina la piccola frazione  la villa oggi Redaelli. Attorno a questa dimora si è avvicendata nell'ultimo mezzo millennio una quantità indefinibile di personaggi che furono alternativamente protagonisti o comparse di vicende festose, gioiose e tragiche.

Nel Quattrocento le monache del vicino monastero di S. Maria Maddalena fecero del luogo un fertile podere i cui prodotti imbandirono i refettori del cenobio lecchese fino al 1789, quando la tenuta di Brogno fu' venduta all'asta e aggiudicata a Gian Giuseppe Airoldi.

Gli Airoldi di Brogno trasformarono  il preesistente rustico delle monache in una grande  casa colonica, ma, a metà dell’Ottocento,  furono travolti da spietati creditori. Giunse in loro soccorso il ricchissimo zio milanese Giuseppe Gargantini Piatti che acquistò all'asta e salvò da ingloriose speculazioni il podere di Brogno.

In soli quattro anni - su progetto dell’ ingegnere Riccardo Badoni,– la vecchia  masseria Airoldi fu trasformata in una eclettica villa dal curioso aspetto alpino, che divenne la scenografia delle bucoliche villeggiature estive dei Gargantini Piatti.

Nel 1929 l'edificio venne  acquistato da Alfredo Redaelli principale e coraggioso fondatore di un rinomato vellutificio che per decenni dominò il settore nel contesto industriale nazionale e oltre.

Di certo Alfredo portava nel sangue i geni di una dinastia di intraprendenti personaggi. Il bisnonno materno, Marc Antonio Galloni, che aveva meritato la carica di Regio Meccanico dell’Impero d’Austria per le sue geniali invenzioni; il nonno, Francesco Redaelli, che  aveva gettato le basi dei capitali familiari con la sua professione di gabelliere; il padre, Savino Redaelli, generoso patriota che aveva partecipato alle campagne garibaldine.

Oggi Brogno continua a essere un luogo in cui architettura, paesaggio e tradizione convivono in  silenzioso equilibrio con le alte e severe pareti rocciose del monte S. Martino. Certo, molte cose nel corso del tempo sono cambiate, ma nulla in fondo ha scalfito l'identità di questa oasi lecchese dove, come decantava il noto architetto milanese Luigi Broggi, ancor oggi "si conduce una vita di tranquillità e di pace".



L' AUTORE:

Francesco D’Alessio, è un giovane ingegnere, storico per passione, meticoloso e acuto perlustratore degli archivi storici della nostra regione.  Ha scritto diversi volumi  sulla storia dell’industria e delle famiglie industriali di Lecco.


LA CAMPAGNA: 

Dopo il  meticoloso lavoro di un anno, tra la ricerca per gli archivi e le parrocchie di Lecco, Como,  Milano, Pavia, Vigevano,  le visite sul campo e la raccolta di memorie, materiale e testimonianze, il libro e' scritto e pronto per la stampa.

Con il vostro contributo potremo stamparne un numero sufficiente di copie per conservare la memoria e la tradizione della casa e della famiglia.

Aiutateci a completare il progetto!


LE VOCI: Brogno,  luogo del cuore 

"Il progetto di ristrutturazione è stato ovviamente molto condizionato dal fattore affettivo che mi vincola indissolubilmente alla casa, da me frequentata assiduamente fin dalla più tenera età. Un'infinità di ricordi, sensazioni ed emozioni mi legano e mi legheranno sempre a questo edificio e alle persone che lo hanno abitato: certo tutti i miei familiari e le persone che aiutavano in casa, ma fondamentalmente i miei nonni. In particolare, di mio nonno Riccardo ricordo la silenziosa ma autorevole presenza. Le altrettanto silenziose passeggiate lungo i sentieri dei dintorni, dove spesso lo accompagnavo discretamente. L'ascolto dei suoi parchi ricordi di scalatore della prima guardia. Non posso dimenticare il fascino del suo laboratorio in cui lui passava ore e ore a inventare e  fabbricare ogni sorta di oggetti e strumenti d'uso quotidiano; o l'armadio pieno di piccoli cassetti e scatole, ove con meticolosa precisione riponeva i suoi attrezzi e classificava ogni genere di piccola minuteria. Questo creare e fare da sé (e per tre) è uno dei lasciti e degli insegnamenti più profondi che mi sono rimasti di lui. Di mia nonna Rosa ricordo l'affetto pratico (tipicamente nordico) di chi accudisce e si prende cura senza troppe smancerie; la sua incessante attività organizzativa nel gestire la casa e i suoi abitanti; il sottile senso dello humour e dell'ironia che spesso stupiva".                 Vincenzo Strambio de Castillia, architetto

... "Al di sopra della casa c'erano rive coltivate che conducevano ad un piano più ampio dal quale si poteva guardare la valle oltre il lago. I miei bisnonni ci avevano piantato degli alberi e chiamavamo il posto “i tre pini” anche se gli alberi erano cipressi e molti di più di tre. Andavamo lassù a fare i picnic, con i cugini.   Ignorando il sentiero ci arrampicavamo su per le ripide pendici attaccandoci all'erba alta.  La discesa era esaltante. I più scivolavano, altri camminavano inclinati come capre di montagna, i temerari correvano. Braccia e gambe in tutte le direzioni, rotolavamo fino alla riva successiva ". Maria Luban 2014.

venduta all'asta e aggiudicata a Gian Giuseppe Airoldi.
Gli Airoldi di Brogno
trasformarono  il preesistente rustico
delle monache in una grande  casa colonica, ma, a metà
dell’Ottocento,  furono travolti da
spietati creditori. Giunse in loro soccorso il ricchissimo zio milanese
Giuseppe Gargantini Piatti che acquistò all'asta e salvò da ingloriose
speculazioni il podere di Brogno.
In soli quattro anni - su progetto dell’ ingegnere Riccardo Badoni,– la
vecchia  masseria Airoldi fu trasformata in una eclettica villa dal
curioso aspetto alpino, che divenne la scenografia delle bucoliche
villeggiature estive dei Gargantini Piatti.
Nel 1929 l'edificio venne  acquistato da Alfredo Redaelli principale e
coraggioso fondatore di un rinomato vellutificio che per decenni dominò il
settore nel contesto industriale nazionale e oltre. 
Di certo Alfredo portava nel sangue i geni di una dinastia di intraprendenti
personaggi. Il bisnonno materno, Marc Antonio Galloni, che aveva meritato la
carica di Regio Meccanico dell’Impero d’Austria per le sue geniali invenzioni;
il nonno, Francesco Redaelli, che  aveva
gettato le basi dei capitali familiari con la sua professione di gabelliere; il
padre, Savino Redaelli, generoso patriota che aveva partecipato alle campagne
garibaldine.
Oggi Brogno continua a essere un luogo in cui architettura, paesaggio
e tradizione convivono in  silenzioso equilibrio con le alte e severe
pareti rocciose del monte S. Martino. Certo, molte cose nel corso del tempo
sono cambiate, ma nulla in fondo ha scalfito l'identità di questa oasi lecchese
dove, come decantava il noto architetto milanese Luigi Broggi, ancor oggi "si
conduce una vita di tranquillità e di pace".


L' AUTORE:Francesco D’Alessio, è un giovane ingegnere, storico per passione, meticoloso e acuto perlustratore degli archivi storici della nostra regione.  Ha scritto diversi volumi  sulla storia dell’industria e delle famiglie industriali di Lecco.LA CAMPAGNA: Dopo il  meticoloso lavoro di un anno, tra la ricerca per gli archivi e le parrocchie di Lecco, Como,  Milano, Pavia, Vigevano,  le visite sul campo e la raccolta di memorie, materiale e testimonianze, il libro e' scritto e pronto per la stampa. Con il vostro contributo potremo stamparne un numero sufficiente di copie per conservare la memoria e la tradizione della casa e della famiglia.Aiutateci a completare il progetto!
LE VOCI: Brogno,  luogo del cuore 

"Il
progetto di ristrutturazione è stato ovviamente molto condizionato dal fattore
affettivo che mi vincola indissolubilmente alla casa, da me frequentata
assiduamente fin dalla più tenera età. Un'infinità di ricordi, sensazioni ed
emozioni mi legano e mi legheranno sempre a questo edificio e alle persone che
lo hanno abitato: certo tutti i miei familiari e le persone che aiutavano in
casa, ma fondamentalmente i miei nonni. In particolare, di mio nonno Riccardo
ricordo la silenziosa ma autorevole presenza. Le altrettanto silenziose
passeggiate lungo i sentieri dei dintorni, dove spesso lo accompagnavo
discretamente. L'ascolto dei suoi parchi ricordi di scalatore della prima
guardia. Non posso dimenticare il fascino del suo laboratorio in cui lui
passava ore e ore a inventare e  fabbricare ogni sorta di oggetti e
strumenti d'uso quotidiano; o l'armadio pieno di piccoli cassetti e scatole,
ove con meticolosa precisione riponeva i suoi attrezzi e classificava ogni
genere di piccola minuteria. Questo creare e fare da sé (e per tre) è uno dei
lasciti e degli insegnamenti più profondi che mi sono rimasti di lui. Di
mia nonna Rosa ricordo l'affetto pratico (tipicamente nordico) di chi accudisce
e si prende cura senza troppe smancerie; la sua incessante attività
organizzativa nel gestire la casa e i suoi abitanti; il sottile senso
dello humour e dell'ironia che spesso
stupiva".                 Vincenzo
Strambio de Castillia, architetto
...
"Al di sopra della casa c'erano rive coltivate che conducevano ad un piano
più ampio dal quale si poteva guardare la valle oltre il lago. I miei bisnonni
ci avevano piantato degli alberi e chiamavamo il posto “i tre pini” anche se
gli alberi erano cipressi e molti di più di tre. Andavamo lassù a fare i
picnic, con i cugini.   Ignorando il sentiero ci arrampicavamo su per
le ripide pendici attaccandoci all'erba alta.  La discesa era esaltante. I
più scivolavano, altri camminavano inclinati come capre di montagna, i temerari
correvano. Braccia e gambe in tutte le direzioni, rotolavamo fino alla riva
successiva ". Maria Luban 2014.

story:
Short Summary

'A Wandering Poem' is exactly what the name describes. A project born out of a spiritual journey, and a strong passion for the poetic form of the written word, the desire to merge them, and to create a work that will speak by itself.

The tortuous road will stretch and bend, through Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Servia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Kosovo, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Iran, Pakistan and the final destination, India.

For each day on the road, a poem will emerge, seizing inspiration from the ride, the characters, the landscapes, the beauty of the world, human kindness, freedom.

Differently from the usual travel journals, this one promises to be of a more abstract nature, an emotional imprint, an heterodox description of an unorthodox trip.

I have set myself the challenge of forcing the search for inspiration, of forcing the act of writing, and of forcing myself through a though area of the world.

The objective: to come back from my trip and publish. Wandering poems accompanied by photographs, emotional postcards of the world's exoticism, the soul of the road on paper.

I'm counting with your interest in my work, and with your support, to make the publishing possible, to help bring my work into the world, in electronic and physical formats.

We are all wanderers, lost, in one way or the other, but we all have an undeniable emotional connection with the universe around us. My desire is to bring the story of my trip, of my heart and of my soul, just in front of you, so that you can experience all that I will experience, so that you can travel with me through fallen empires, spice markets, desert landscapes, human faces touched by the sun, turbans, beards, immortal eyes.

Come with me on this trip, the pleasure is all mine.


What We Need & What You Get

I have set the fund-raising objective of 1.500€ which is the sufficient amount of funds necessary to publish my work. 
Based on online print-on-demand services, I have made an estimation of how much it would cost me to self-publish my book, let's say printing an initial number of 200 physical copies and an e-book. 
The trip requires no necessary additional funding, as that is already covered by the budget I have defined for those 6 months.
The promised perks will be :
  • For a contribution of 5€ you will get an e-book in any of the common electronic book formats (ePub, AZW, LIT, PDF, ODF, Mobi), accompanied with a customized postcard, made with selected photos from the trip. 
  • For a contribution of 15€ you will get a physical copy of the paperback book, accompanied with a signature and customized dedication matching the feedback I'll have by exchanging a couple of emails with you :) I will also include a postcard with a selected photo from the trip.  
  • The poems will initially be written in Portuguese, and promptly translated by myself to English, for the first publishing batch. Later I plan to have them translated to French, Spanish, Italian and Greek. 
If the goal is not reached, I will do my best to still bring to the world, at least the number of copies that were promised in the pre-order, even if that involves additional investment from my part. 

I am currently discussing and negotiating with some Portuguese publishers in order to see if I can get a publishing compromise, and some sort of publicity/marketing support from an established actor in the publishing business.


    The Impact

    Because this project means to be original, and different from the usual travel journals, you will be helping and contributing to the birth of something freshly new and innovative.
    If you like to read travel journals, if you like poetry, and if you're interested in following my adventure, then you meet all the requirements for being a part of this crowd-funding.
    I am a dedicated individual, and practically every project I have ever put my hands to, has reached a conclusion (please do check my personal page to see my previous work in computer science and in music), and this project will definitely not be different.

      Risks & Challenges

      Of course there are some risks associated to this project, and the main one would be the feasibility of the trip. I am currently undergoing the process of acquiring all the visas, vaccines, etc. 
      Because the places I will cross are relatively unstable right now - with ISIL sweeping through Syria and Iraq moving closer to Turkey and Iran, and Pakistan in a state of civil unrest - there is definitely a probability that I will be denied passage through some of those countries. In that case, I do not intend to stop the trip, but I will try to find a work-around, to reach my next destination without putting my life in risk, of course.
      There is also the chance of something happening to me on the road - which I find very unlikely - that would preclude me from writing and reaching the end of the project. For this eventuality, I would definitely refund all the donations, in case that the project could not be completed for some external reason. 

      Finally, there is the risk of arriving home with a complete work, and not being able to find a publishing support, someone who would bet on me. For that, the contingency plan is that of self-publishing. If no publisher will support the project, I will not let my work die without seeing the light of day. I will use the raised funds, and if necessary personal funds, to make a print-on-demand, and to bring the work to your hands, as promised. 


        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't or don't want to contribute financially to my project, there are other ways you could help me get through with my endeavor. 
        • Since I will be mainly hitchhiking and couchsurfing, if you know people or have any contacts in the countries I will pass through, it would be of great value for me to have some local contacts, that I could reach in case of need.
        • You can and should help me diffuse my project, sharing it through your peers, your social networks, even your work colleagues. You can also share it through the tools provided by Indiegogo, right here on this website!
        • If you know, or are in contact with any kind of independent publisher, please do forward me their contact, I'd love to propose my work to them.

        What do I expect to get from this experience?

        Apart from producing a work of poetry and photography, there are other things that I expect to find on this journey. Of course, the cliché spiritual journey could not be defined without the phrase 'I will be looking for myself', which indeed is one of the main motivations for my trip. But apart from that, I will be moving (ideally) by hitchhiking and sleeping at people's places through couchsurfing. Why? Because apart from being much more optimized in terms of budget, there is a world of kindness and goodness waiting to be found. I believe that the majority of people in the world are truly good-hearted, and I want to test that theory with this trip. 
        I also want to prove that it is possible to make an incredible trip with few money, given that you are ready to let go of a bit of comfort, and also, I want to demystify a bit the general idea that people have of the middle east, especially Iran and Pakistan. I believe that they are incredible countries with such a cultural richness, who unfortunately are obscured by the media, on account of their political and religious circumstances.

story:
What is the Quarterly?

Think of it as a social enterprise publication, a kind of fair trade for creativity: high standards based on an ethical revenue share that tries to do the right thing. 

It’s a publication with a focus in the field of photography, featuring the work of a wide range of talent from around the world and a variety of different backgrounds, from fashion, to photojournalism, travel to landscape and portraiture and so on.

It’s a submission-based journal that aims to release 4 issues a year, where each issue has a theme and creatives are tasked with sharing their ideas for submission. Those who have their ideas accepted for publication are then supported to bring their concepts to life, in whatever way we can.

The Quarterly is about challenging, provoking thought, embracing the awesome, championing talent and above all bringing value back to creatives and their work, in our own bold way. It’s not a new idea but we kinda think it’s daring, will likely ruffle a few feathers, and put some noses out of joint—especially when creative talent is often exploited and their real value goes unrecognised and underappreciated. It’s time for a creative journal with guts and integrity.

HOW IT WORKS

  • Ethical: Once we cover print costs, the profit made from selling each issue will be split evenly amongst everyone involved. All of the creativity, none of the exploitation. That’s what we mean by social enterprise. We want to challenge and change the way the current industry works.
  • Exposure: With a small initial print run, we can’t promise the moon. There won’t be international, Times Square levels of fame but in time, and with your support, we really believe The Quarterly can become biblically epic.
  • Passion: The design, photography, direction and editing are all created by a community of creatives with the same passion. No egos here, just honest to goodness love for our work and a drive to do things differently.
  • High standards: We only accept submissions from members of our community, The Creative Book website as contributors of each issue. Joining is free and although we accept both established and aspiring creatives, being a member won’t guarantee you a spot on the team. It’s all about the idea and concept of the submission first. The website allows us to ensure the quality of work remains high and the content forever awesome.
  • Invest: To get involved, we ask, never demand, but ask contributors to invest in each issue. Not much mind you, just a bit more than the cost of each issue, which ensures that everyone is fully committed to the project. And because karma comes full circle, you get what you give—and then some more. The less print cost we have to cover, the bigger the profit the creatives have to split.
  • Exclusivity: The content created for The Quarterly will always be created specifically for each issue. You will never see content that has already been published elsewhere, it’s all totally bespoke and supercalifragilistically awesome.

 

Above: Ying Adams applying the finishing touches to her model for her editorial.

 

THE REASON

We’ve become disillusioned with how a lot of creative magazines run things. We don’t agree with the way that some publications make money through advertising and through selling copies and at the same time not pay for the content creatives put their time and effort (and blood and sweat and tears and the odd bit of snot) into producing.

Free work doesn’t pay the bills. The promise of exposure won’t buy groceries. And putting in the gargantuan amount of time and effort into one’s work without getting anything back except the dream of getting discovered through exposure isn’t dignified. More often than not it’s an empty dream too.

From the very beginning, our goal has always been to do the right thing. Call it a philosophy, call it an ethical approach, it’s what constantly drives the Creative Book project forward.

We sat down and came up with an idea: to create a publication that recognises true talent, promises a fair share of the profits and won’t ever exploit artists. 

It’s been a defining experience, a challenging one and an incredibly rewarding one so far but there’s still so much more to do. 

Which is where we are now: with an awesome dream and a community of battle ready creatives about to start production, we need your help to get the Quarterly out into the world.

 

 

Above: Photographer Roo Lewis gives a sneak preview of his his submission which will be featured in the first issue.

 

THE QUARTERLY ITSELF

We don’t have advertising on our website (The Creative Book) and nor will we have any in our publication (The Quarterly). It’s something we’re strongly against, spending money on a magazine that is overloaded with advertising and the odd page of original content really doesn’t work for us. We’re creating a content rich publication that tells a story from front cover to back. 

It’ll look more like a beautifully designed art book than a magazine, with high quality paper stock in a smaller size that fits nicely on your shelf or your bag for reading on the train. We're looking at producing something which is A5 in size, 148mm x 205mm at the very minimum and of around 100 pages. But if you guys really want this to happen, then we'll look to producing a bigger version.

Now, since we haven’t produced the first issue yet, we can’t show you what the finished journal will look like, but we've provided a few behind the scene images of the editorials currently being produced for the quarterly.

Above: The Awesome Cynthia Miller working on the Quarterly logo for us.

 

WHERE YOUR DONATIONS WILL GO (in the interest of transparency and always being honest)

The funds raised will directly support the promotion, development and production of The Quarterly. Your generous donations will allow us to shout about The Quarterly from the rooftops, get the message out there, develop an online store from which to distribute the journal as well as help us publish larger quantities of the issues. 

Now for those of you not able to donate anything but would like to help out, we're always looking for shiny, happy people who'll help us promote the Quarterly and help us fight the good fight, either through social media mentions, to blog posts and so on.

We really want to push this as far as possible and reward all those who have gotten involved. We hope you’ll still get involved and help spread the word as without your help, support and talent, the project would still be a distant dream. If you do have any questions, please feel free to get in touch. Thank you! 

 

Above: Neil Golgoi and gives a snapshot of his submission. We're rather hyped about this shoot.

 

THE CREATIVE BOOK PROJECT (in case your interested)

It started with one guy and an idea to create a resource that would be useful to both aspiring and established creatives and their potential clients. Which lead to the creation of The Creative Book, our community site, which whilst still in it’s infancy. Everything has been done on a shoestring budget via a grassroots approach while managing a full time job. 

We’ve had a pretty incredible and positive response from artists the world over and our experience of putting The Creative Book project together inspired The Quarterly. If you want to read more about what inspired these projects, head over to our site

We hope you’ll still get involved and help spread the word as without your help, support and talent, the project would still be a distant dream. If you do have any questions, please feel free to get in touch. Thank you! 
 
Above: Neil Golgoi and gives a snapshot of his submission. We're rather hyped about this shoot.
 

THE CREATIVE BOOK PROJECT (in case your interested)

It started with one guy and an idea to create a resource that would be useful to both aspiring and established creatives and their potential clients. Which lead to the creation of The Creative Book, our community site, which whilst still in it’s infancy. Everything has been done on a shoestring budget via a grassroots approach while managing a full time job. 
We’ve had a pretty incredible and positive response from artists the world over and our experience of putting The Creative Book project together inspired The Quarterly. If you want to read more about what inspired these projects, head over to our site

story:
Long Story Short

Hi!  My name is Beth Ragen, I am 34 years old and I currently reside in Oregon.  I grew up in Iowa, for the most part in the middle of what felt like nowhere, and went from no town, to small town, to bigger town and back again.  At the age of 29, I decided enough was enough and I left Iowa behind on a Greyhound bus headed for the Pacific Northwest. I knew in my heart my destiny waited for me here, and I am sad to say that I was wrong. 

I have spent my entire adult life working, because thats what I was raised to do.  I had dreams of adventure when I was younger, I wanted to do and see things, but in the end the need to pay bills and be a productive adult won out.  It occured to me a few months ago that I am not where I need to be, and I made the decision to try and find it.  Home as a concept has been elusive, and I want more than anything to say that I am "home". 

I have always been a bit of an artist, when I was younger I drew, up until the point where I told myself I couldn't, and then it became true.  When I was in high school I picked up a camera, and photography renewed the notion that I could be an artist of sorts, and while the camera left my hands for a while, once I picked it up again the passion renewed.  I do not consider myself a photographer, but I would like to, and part of this journey is very much about that.  When I was younger, I also wrote, and same as with drawing, along the way I told myself I couldn't, so I stopped.  I realize now that I can, and I should and that I will.

Once I made the decision to once again pick up and move my life, I decided to so so with more purpose than I've done before.  I am going to find out what home means to the people I know, and the people I have yet to meet.  I am going to accomplish this by hopping on a Greyhound bus, and taking my time getting to know the people in my life all over again, and hopefully a few strangers along the way.  My final destination will more than likely be somewhere in the south, so thats where I will be spending the majority of this journey.  I will hit as many places as I can, spending time with friends, family and strangers living their lives and finding out what home means to them and why they are where they are.  I will record this trip via photographs, some moving pictures and through the written word.  When it is all said and done, I will write a book and will hopefully have a better idea what home is, even if I haven't found mine yet. You can check out my current writings, photography and general info at www.bethragen.com.

 

Help me if you can!

What I am asking for and why I need it. I am trying to raise 5,000 buckarinos, below is a breakdown of what I am going to use the funding for:

  • $1200 to $1500 for a new camera and gear: I have outgrown my current equipment, and it lacks a video feature. It is getting on in age and doesn't function the way it used to. It also lacks the megapixels needed to do any large scale printing, and this limits me greatly. 
  • $1000 for bus fare:  Added to what I am currently saving, this will proivde me with at least 10 additional stops on my journey, giving me a greater range of people experiences. 
  • $1000 to self publish: Based on what I have researched, this seems to be the minium I'll need to get the job done right and get this out there.
  • $500 to help keep me fed on the road: While I will be staying with friends and family, I cannot expect them to feed me as well.  This will provide me with the funds to help with meals and food on the road.
  • $500 for incentives: This may be a overestimating the actual cost, but I would rather be safe than sorry. Printing, shipping, postage and materials cost have been included in this estimate.
  • $500 for emergency medical situations: Planning for the worst is not always fun, but I am looking at up to three months on the road and who knows what can happen.

 

I have some awesome perks including correspondence from the road, prints, framed photographs and a copy of the book when all is said and done.  I have thought very hard about what I would want, and I might have gotten carried away, but I want you to feel like you are getting your money's worth! Please note that certain incentives such as prints and postcards will be available before the stated June 2014 delivery date. 

If all the funds aren't raised, I will make sure incentives are covered then put the rest towards the trip itself. I will do as much as I can with what is generously given.

What this means to me

I have always lived life very purposely, but its never been my purpose.  I did the things I was supposed to, that I was raise to do.  I got a job, I took responsiblity for myself, I've taken care of others, but I've never really done anything to serve myself.  I really need to have faith in myself, to believe that I can do something other than work and be responsible.  By donating to my campaign, you have shown that you believe in me and that helps me to believe in myself. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that life happens, and we cannot always help in the ways that are asked of us, but even if you cannot contribute monetarily, if you have faith in me and this project, help spread the word:

  • Share on facebook, twitter, word of mouth, anything you can to get the word out.  Point them to my website at www.bethragen.com where they can learn more about me and who I am.
  • Indiegogo also has some pretty cool sharing tools, take advantage of them and help get the word out.

Thank you so much for your time and consideration, it means the world.

story:
Christmas Press is a brand-new small publishing house, specialising in beautiful picture books, and owned and managed by a collective of three creators, all hailing from the New England region of northern NSW, Australia: writer Sophie Masson, illustrator David Allan and illustrator/designer Fiona McDonald.

We're looking for your support to help us publish our launch title, a gorgeous picture book called Two Trickster Tales from Russia. Two Trickster Tales from Russia contains two much-loved folk tales from Russia, with the first being Masha and the Bear and the second being The Rooster with the Golden Crest.

These entertaining tales, with their endearing and resourceful characters are perfect both for reading aloud to small children and also for older children—and adults!—to read on their own. Retold in bright, lively prose and verse by well-known children's author Sophie Masson, the tales are illustrated by David Allan in a style inspired by classic Russian children's illustration, with glorious full-colour spreads, delicate line drawings, and sepia washes, while the sensitive design by Fiona McDonald is also in keeping with that classic look.

We're looking for your help with printing costs, for a limited-edition first run of 500 A4 size paperback copies, printed in Australia as we are believers in keeping our country's printers in work too! We are planning to launch the book in late October this year.

You can donate an amount as small as $10 or as high as $1,000, with lots of wonderful perks. The $25 donation is basically a pre-order for the book. (All amounts are in US dollars)Have a look at what we're offering! And please share with all your friends and contacts!

story:
In August, Mikhail Gorbachev gave an interview with the German news magazine Der Spiegel, marking the twentieth anniversary of the attempted coup against his presidency that hastened the fall of the Soviet Union. In it, he was highly critical of the Russian Federation’s former president and current prime minister, Vladimir Putin, who will return to his former office in the Kremlin at the conclusion of the current election cycle.

 

“Sometimes United Russia reminds me of the old Soviet Communist Party,” Gorbachev said when asked about the pro-Putin party. “Putin wants to stay in power, but not so that he can finally solve our most pressing problems: education, health care, poverty. The people are not being asked, and the parties are puppets of the regime.” Or as Anna Politkovskaya said before she gunned down in her Moscow apartment building in 2006: “We are hurtling back into a Soviet abyss.”

 

For the past twelve months, Moscow-based journalists in need of a story have liked to tout the idea that Russia might finally have a real presidential race on its hands. This idea, which always smacked of a beat-up, was finally dashed on the rocks of the United Russia congress on September 24, when incumbent President Dmitri Medvedev proposed that Putin return to the presidency. After stepping down from the role only four years ago, Putin will now be eligible to rule until 2024. If his first two terms maimed Russia's fledgling democracy, the mere fact of his return for a third might be said to have finally killed it.

 

Putin, Medvedev and United Russia have all experienced sharp declines in their poll numbers since the beginning of this year. The example of the Arab Spring, not to mention that of the post-election protests in Lukashenko’s Belarus in December 2010, remains fresh in the minds of many, including plenty who otherwise might have tended towards apathy. Protests against the regime have popped up sporadically throughout this year. Should there be any signs of electoral fraud when Putin's inevitable victory is announced in March, Russia will be the place to watch. The only question that remains about this election is whether or not the electorate will stand for it.

 

In 2010, IndieGoGo contributors helped freelance foreign correspondent Matthew Clayfield and photojournalist Austin Andrews travel around Mexico between that country’s Bicentenary of Independence and its Centenary of Revolution. The work they produced during that period appeared in The Australian, Crikey and RealClearWorld, as well as on their website, Disposable Words. A book based on their trip, Blood Still Drips: A Mexican Journal, is currently in the works.

 

Matthew is now planning to spend three months in the Commonwealth of Independent States during the lead up to, and immediate aftermath of, Russia’s presidential election. Taking in Siberia, Moscow, St Petersburg, Belarus, Ukraine, the Southern Federal District and the Northern Caucasus, his freelance dispatches and blog posts will provide a first-hand look, at once both epic and intimate, political and personal, at a Potemkin democracy and its disaffected electorate at a moment that many fear represents the completion of its political regression.

The trip is to be the first of an estimated five through the countries of the former USSR that will later constitute a book-length study of the region nearly a quarter of a century after the the collapse of the Soviet Union. Reader contributions will constitute approximately one quarter of this first trip's total budget and will go towards travel, accommodation and equipment.


Links


  • Matthew's piece of Western apologists' defence of Putin's return to the Kremlin, 'Putin apologists line up to justify the ruling tandem's bitch slap to democracy' (Crikey, 10 October 2011);
  • Matthew's blog post on crowd-sourced journalism, 'Sans Masthead' (Emerging Writers' Festival Blog, 30 September 2011);
  • Matthew's piece on Medvedev's endorsement of Putin for the presidency, 'Putin's endorsement a surprise despite its inevitability' (Crikey, 26 September 2011);
  • Matthew's blog post on reader-funded journalism and why he thinks it is the future business model of the form;
  • Matthew's op-ed about the 2012 Russian presidential election: 'Vladimir and Dmitri Go Cycling' (Disposable Words, 25 March 2011)
  • Matthew's Disposable Words coverage of Mexico between its Bicentenary of Independence and Centenary of Revolution: Between Two Anniversaries (co-created with Austin Andrews)
  • Other pieces of foreign correspondence from Matthew's time in Mexico and Cuba: 'The last days of casa Castro' (The Australian, 3 January 2011), 'A town kicks against cartel rule' (The Weekend Australian, 11 December 2010), 'Reporters suffer in Mexican mayhem' (The Australian, 27 September 2010)
  • Matthew and Austin interviewed by The Australian's Geoff Elliott about Mexican drug violence and the dangerous it poses to journalists (The Australian Media Series, Boardroom Radio Australia, 27 September 2010).

story:
About This Project –
Humanity Inspired – Powered By You!

I have spent more than 30 years working with the homeless, raising funds for battered women shelters and helping bring better living conditions to Africa and other countries like India. I wasn’t a rich guy while I did all this – just a guy who was living Mahatma Ghandi’s advice of being the change I wished to see in the world.

For a long time I have wanted to write and publish a book about Little Ideas that I hope will inspire people everywhere to do little things that can have some pretty large consequences. These Little Ideas could ripple out to the ends of our planet and enough Little Ideas can create massive impact. The book is titled:

I also have a Blog on this topic: http://littleideascanchangetheworld.blogspot.com/

As a Backer you will have the opportunity to throw your pebble, stone or rock into the sea of humanity and our planet and watch the effect as ripples of change spread out into our world. This is not MY book but instead a book for all of us.

Why This Book?

Repeatedly over the years people have asked me “What can I do with my limited resources?” “Can one person really make much difference in the world?”

I also know that I am an ideas guy and I would like to invite other idea people like me to help me with this project. Ideally I would like to see a series of books on this subject with hundreds of ideas that would suit the resources, environments, energies and preferences of people all over the world.
(To view samples of some ideas please visit my blog – see my profile page)

In The Tipping Point Malcolm Gladwell says “little changes can have big effects” and that “change happens not gradually but at one dramatic moment‘. Maybe you have heard about The Shift taking place on the planet however I think for this ‘shift’ to take place we have to reach a ‘tipping point’ and we are not there yet. This book – these Little Ideas – spread and acted upon could be what is needed to flip the switch.

Funding
I have wanted to act on this project for a long time but never had the time. Now I have the time because I am suddenly unemployed but I don’t have the money. That’s when I thought about all of you at Indiegogo and had this crazy idea that maybe there were enough people out there that wanted to fuel this project; that I didn’t have to do this alone, that this didn’t have to be MY project. I DO NOT seek glory or fame, instead my heart burns for change.

I want to work on this full time for the next few months or as long as the project needs me to get it to the Tipping Point. I have chosen $28,000 as that would insure that I can focus on this project. I know it is a lot of money but I want to do it right and I want to make sure I don’t run out of money.

I hope to inspire people to purchase multiple copies to give away so that we create a movement of Little Ideas, each one causing little ripples and collectively causing a Tsunami that shifts our planet into a new reality.

Am I crazy? Am I a Dreamer? YOU can determine how big this becomes!

story:
There’s more to Nashville’s arts scene these days than just country music – the message of popular TV shows notwithstanding. Nashville is home to one of America’s best regional orchestras (a seven-time Grammy winner), fabulous art museums and galleries, adventurous opera, hard-bopping jazz, fun and thought-provoking theater, and lots more. It’s an exhilarating arts scene, to be sure, and it definitely demands serious journalistic attention.

ArtsNash was founded in the spring of 2012 for that very purpose. The mission of this nonprofit journalism company is to provide comprehensive coverage of Nashville’s thriving arts scene, posting on our website the sorts of high-quality professional reviews that used to be found in daily newspapers. ArtsNash publishes the work of some of Music City’s finest reviewers, including former Tennessean critic Evans Donnell (theater, opera, film) and long-time Nashville Scene scribes Joe Nolan (visual arts), John Pitcher (classical music, dance) and Ron Wynn (jazz).

During its first season of operation, ArtsNash posted over 400 reviews, and the website received more than 100,000 unique visits.

·  ArtsNash is providing an important public service. The website is the only professional journalism organization in the city that routinely reviews the concerts of the Grammy Award-winning Nashville Symphony. ArtsNash was also the only media outlet to review such recent performances as the world premiere of Nashville Ballet’s “Peter Pan” and Nashville Opera’s “The Pearl Fishers.”

·  ArtsNash’s reviews are all being stored in an online archive, which is already beginning to constitute the most important historical record of Nashville’s vibrant arts scene in the early 21st century.

In addition, the site has established important regional and national partnerships with such noted groups as NowPlayingNashville (Nashville’s premier online calendar), ArtsATL (Atlanta’s terrific online arts journal) and the delightfully provocative Clyde Fitch Report. Since ArtsNash is committed to the long-term success of the arts, it has also established an internship program to train the next generation of arts journalists.

The success of ArtsNash during its first season has allowed us to market a few ads on our home page, bringing in a small amount of money to help defray expenses while providing other nonprofits with an inexpensive means to market their important endeavors. What the ad money does not do, however, is provide ArtsNash with the funds it needs to pay its writers, who up to now have all donated their services. ArtsNash is a nonprofit (we are incorporated in Tennessee and our application for federal tax exempt status is pending), and just like public television and public radio we depend on the support and generosity of the public for our survival. That’s why we’re launching this Indiegogo campaign to raise $5,000.

What will the money be used for? All of it (100 percent) will be used to send our professional writers an embarrassingly small check for each of their reviews. That’s the least that we can do, given the substantial amount of time the writers devote to each piece. The $5,000 would enable us to pay the writers during the winter and early spring of 2014. On Monday, Dec. 2, 2013, we received a letter from the IRS that approved our August 2012 application for tax-exempt status under Section 501 (c) (3) of the Internal Revenue Code, so your contribution is tax deductible under Section 170 of the code.

What will you get besides the option of that deduction? In the larger sense you can feel that you're aiding the cultural life of our community by encouraging serious professional coverage of the local arts scene. This is critical at a time when studies have shown that while journalism coverage of the arts has steadily declined, participation in the arts by members of  the public has steadily increased. The arts matter to more and more of our citizens yet the information they need is coming more frequently from less reliable sources – much of it now amounting to little more than 140-character shout outs. Don’t get us wrong. We love Twitter and use it all the time. But great art doesn’t always lend itself  to analysis by haiku. Good criticism provides us with a template on how to remember and appreciate the great art that we see and hear. And it makes that art unforgettable in every sense of that word. With your help ArtsNash wants to give the region’s arts scene the sort of serious professional attention it deserves.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone can contribute money at this time. You can help by spreading the word, however: send people to our website, refer them to our Facebook page and, yes, our Twitter profile, and of course post a link to this campaign through your social media accounts. Thanks in advance for anything and everything you can do to aid not only arts journalism but more importantly the coverage and promotion of the cultural offerings that strengthen our society in so many ways!

-- John Pitcher, ArtsNash President and Co-Founder

more to Nashville’s arts scene these days than just country music – the message
of popular TV shows notwithstanding. Nashville is home to one of America’s best
regional orchestras (a seven-time Grammy winner), fabulous art museums and
galleries, adventurous opera, hard-bopping jazz, fun and thought-provoking
theater, and lots more. It’s an exhilarating arts scene, to be sure, and it definitely
demands serious journalistic attention. 
ArtsNash was founded in
the spring of 2012 for that very purpose. The mission of this nonprofit
journalism company is to provide comprehensive coverage of Nashville’s thriving
arts scene, posting on our website the sorts of high-quality professional
reviews that used to be found in daily newspapers. ArtsNash publishes the work
of some of Music City’s finest reviewers, including former Tennessean critic Evans Donnell (theater, opera, film) and
long-time Nashville Scene scribes Joe
Nolan (visual arts), John Pitcher (classical music, dance) and Ron Wynn (jazz).

During
its first season of operation, ArtsNash posted over 400 reviews, and the
website received more than 100,000 unique visits.
·

is providing an important public service. The website is the only professional
journalism organization in the city that routinely reviews the concerts of the
Grammy Award-winning Nashville Symphony. ArtsNash was also the only media
outlet to review such recent performances as the world premiere of Nashville
Ballet’s “Peter Pan” and Nashville Opera’s “The Pearl Fishers.”
·

story:
Did you know a 3rd Tower fell on 9/11?

For 12 years many of our government's policies have been based on false information, and we don't want to live in that kind of world.  We want our policies to be based on sound evidence, and on the truth.  Rethink911 is a global campaign that stretches from Canada to Australia, to raise public awareness about the science behind 9/11, much of which was largely ignored until today.

The story of building 7 has been swept under the rug by the media, and completely ignored in the September 11 Commission report.  That is why we are buying ads, making videos and sharing them, in the hopes of obtaining an investigation into what really happened on 9/11.  A lot of progress has already been made - All we need to do is keep the ball rolling!  Sign the petition at www.rethink911.org and if you can, donate to the campaign to keep the ads going. 

ReThink911 is coming back to Canada! 
And will be in Vancouver on March 14th.

"The Rethink911 Campaign was launched in September 2013 when simultaneous advertising in 11 Major Cities Globally commenced for 1 month, sending a strong message across the globe.  Whether it was 1 Million per day seeing the Times Square Billboard in New York, or the ads in the subways in Sydney and London, the campaign has brought 9/11 back on the table, so we can build a future that rests on the truth about the causes, and the actions that happened on 9/11.  Since September, the campaign has been repeated in select cities. In NYC, we extended our Times Square Ad and advertised on a billboard right next to the New York Times for one whole month. In March of 2014 ReThink911 is coming back to Canada, with a 17 city tour. The Vancouver event is on March 14th.  We would appreciate your support in helping the ReThink911 "ripple effect" continue to lead millions to awaken and "take truth as the authority, not authority as the truth".

Peace and Knowledge,

ReThink"

What You Can Do

On our own we do not have a lot of power.  But together we can raise awareness, and we can do what the media is not doing.

Be a part of the ReThink911 campaign. Here are a few things you can do to help:

1. Share this video

When this petition reaches one million signers, it will be delivered to the Head of State of every nation that lost citizens in the attacks of September 11, 2001.

2. Sign the petition now

Once you’ve joined our Facebook and Twitter pages, share links to our website, our official video, and the ReThink911 International Petition.

3. Join our Facebook Page

4. Follow us on Twitter

ReThink911 launches new ad campaigns every few months in order to create widespread awareness of the destruction of World Trade Center Building 7, which is a critical component our search for the truth about 9/11.  Please donate today to make the next campaign possible.

5. Donate here on this site to help secure media space, and receive our special perks.

These are just small actions you can take to help this campaign go viral. Visit this page to find the full list of our suggested actions.  

6.  Talk about it!  Talk to your peers, your friends, your colleagues: Don't be afraid to be marginalized.  The more we talk about it, the more comfortable it is for others to join us, and for us to continue the important mission we've embarked on.  

Together we can do this.

story:
My name is Caleb McMillan, I'm a writer for Mises Canada and editor of Rothbard.ca. As an avid reader of history and economics, I'm disappointed by the lack of economically sound history of my country. With the exception of Andrew Smith's British Businessmen and Canadian Confederation, there is virtually no revisionist account of Confederation or the history of Canada. Most historians fall prey to Marxist interpretations or exalt the founders to biblical proportions while ignoring their financial interests. Writing the history of the people who created Canada requires understanding praxeology and applying thymology.

Contributors will help me focus on this project 40 hours a week or more. I don't need much, through couch-surfing and staying in hostels I can keep my expenses down while I spend my days in the library and the Canadian Archives. Contributors will aid the production of a history book that presents the founding of Canada through the lens of purposeful actors. If you enjoy American history as told by Murray Rothbard, Tom Woods and Tom Dilorenzo, then with your help I can tell Canadian history in the same vein.

I need $1200 for living expenses spread over 3 months. Access to primary sources and libraries require either small fees or are taxpayer funded. The $1200 will go toward my room and board as I put in 8 to 12 hour days going through the history and writing the book. I'm already in the process of researching and writing this thing, but with your contribution I can make it my full-time job and have it published in 2014.


In an age of chronic statism and propaganda, Canadians need to know the truth of their history. I'm not trying to tell a story biased toward a libertarian philosophy, but rather the history of Canada as a struggle between state power and social power. For the desire to be free is prominent throughout the history of civilizations and Canada is no different. It's time this history has a chance to be discovered, written and read.

For a sample of my writing, visit www.calebmcmillan.com or http://mises.ca/posts/author/caleb-mcmillan/


Publication of this book will be either through self-publishing or by the Ludwig von Mises Institute of Canada. An online PDF and ePub edition will -- of course -- be free.

story:
THANK YOU FOR GETTING ME TO MY GOAL!


I am so grateful for the amazing response to my campaign. Thank you, thank you, for all of your support - I feel as though you'll all be traveling with me!


 


IMPORTANT CAMPAIGN UPDATE (OCTOBER):

 

SLS Kenya – the writing seminar I was planning to attend in Nairobi and Lamu – has just cancelled their program due to safety and security concerns in Kenya.

 

After serious consideration, I have decided to continue with this project -- going to Kenya to complete my novel -- on my own.

 

I am in the process of figuring out transportation, accommodations, and other arrangements, and I will post details as they get finalized. Please check my “Updates” section for more information. My plan now is to spend less time in Nairobi, no time in Lamu (where the danger seems to be greatest), more time in Kisumu, and the bulk of the month at Kaimosi Mission (which is actually where I most want to be and where I will have more time for writing).

 

I realize this changes the character of this project somewhat, but the creative goal and financial need remain intact. Above is a video that describes the original campaign, and below is the original campaign description --  except for references to SLS Kenya, the content is still accurate.


Please let me know any comments or questions you may have about any of this by using the “Comments” tab above. Thank you for your support and understanding!

 


ORIGINAL CAMPAIGN DESCRIPTION:

 

I’m going to Kenya to complete my novel – and I need your help!

 

My name is David Hallock Sanders. I live in Philadelphia, and I'm writing a novel that's set in the mountain rainforest of western Kenya, where I lived as a child.

 

I’m turning to IndieGoGo to help me get back to Kenya in December for a writing seminar in Nairobi and a return to my old home at Kaimosi Quaker Mission for writing and research – all part of completing my novel in 2012.

 

Why Africa?

 

In the mid-1960s I lived in Kenya at a Quaker mission located right on the equator, but high in the mountain jungle. This was just after Kenyan independence, and my parents were training teachers for the nation's new education system. 


That's me in the small photo at top, standing outside the mission school with some of my classmates.

 

Forty-five years later I'm now writing a novel set in a similar, although fictional, location in Kenya during the mid-sixties. The novel's working title is Busara Road, and it's something of a coming-of-age story for both the main character and the young Kenyan nation. I'm now closing in on a first draft of the novel, helped by several writing residencies at the Pendle Hill Quaker Center and the Virginia Center for the Creative Arts.

 

Recently I was accepted for a very exciting writing program in Africa called SLS Kenya. In December I will spend several weeks in Nairobi and Lamu working with some top African writers as well as novelist Gary Shteyngart.

 

Following the seminar I will travel on my own to western Kenya for more writing and research to complete the novel, as well as for a personal homecoming at the Quaker mission where I lived as a child. It will be my first time back since I was a boy.

 

What your support will fund

 

The total cost of this trip will be about $8,000, even with a tuition prize I won in the SLS International Fiction Competition. It's a daunting amount. About $3,000 of that is for the SLS program fees and the cost of returning to Kaimosi Quaker Mission. The rest is for travel, accommodations, food, supplies, etc..

 

My goal for IndieGoGo is $3,000 to help meet the expenses for the writing program and mission visit.

 

If I'm fortunate enough to exceed that goal, I'll put all additional funds toward the other expenses directly related to completing this trip and the novel.

 

I believe very strongly in this novel. Excerpts from it have already won awards and been published in literary journals and anthologies. Now I invite you to join me in making the completed work a reality.

 

Why go to Kenya now?

 

Now is when I've been accepted to the SLS program. Now is when I've been invited to return to Kaimosi Quaker Mission. And most of all, now is when this trip can most benefit the completion of my novel.

 

I'm at a pivotal moment in my writing career. I've had some successes, including publications, awards, and having my work produced for stage and public radio.


But now I am eager to complete my first novel for publication, and this trip to Kenya will enable me to do exactly that.

 

Your support means everything to me

 

This trip to Kenya will be a crucial catalyst for completing and revising my novel for publication. I would love it if you were able to support this project. Your contribution, right now, however big or small, is very important to reaching my goal. It's easy to do. To back this project just click on "Contribute Now" and pick an amount. You'll see up there on the right some fun perks I'm offering to say thanks for your contribution.

 

I'd also love it if you could spread the word about this project to anyone you think might be interested, by "liking" this site and creating links to it through Facebook, Twitter, emails, and embedding it in your own website, or connecting in any other way you think would be helpful. It's easy to do by using IndieGoGo's share tools. 


And please leave me a comment (or lots of comments!) on my Comments tab to let me know what you think.

 

Thank you!

 

Even if you can't afford to contribute, I really appreciate this opportunity to share with you a project I'm very excited about. I'll be posting updates on the project at IndieGoGo.com, as well as on my own site, BusaraBlog.com – so check those out; and share your thoughts on my Comments tab.

 

Special thanks to Richard Drueding (richarddrueding.com) for the outstanding music on my video. Very special thanks to the members of my team for being there for me in so many ways.

 

And most special thanks to you for taking time to check out my proposal!
